PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  The PPTA is required to: (i) assist the Ministry of Public Works and Utilities (MPWU) to 
plan, design and prioritize investments to improve water supply services in South Tarawa; (ii) 
assess technical suitability, economic, financial and social viability, capacity and institutional 
issues, climate change resilience and address environmental and social safeguards of the 
project,  and  (iii)  identify  measures  to  strengthen  project  implementation  capacity  of 
implementing agencies.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
3.  The PPTA is estimated to cost $950,000 equivalent, of which $800,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-V), and the remaining 
$150,000 by the Multidonor Trust Fund under the Water Financing Partnership Facility1 and 
administered  by  ADB.  The  government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of 
counterpart staff, provision of office space, communication facilities for consultants, and other 
in-kind contributions. The detailed cost estimate is presented in Table A3.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
4.  ADB will provide consultants and management of the PPTA. The total consultant input is 
estimated at 36 person-months, comprising 24 person-months from international consulting 
services and 12 person-months from national consulting services and will be provided over a 
period of 12 months. The firm will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time) using the quality- and cost-based selection 
procedures (90:10) and a simplified technical proposal. Disbursements under the TA will be 
done  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as 
amended from time to time).

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
5.  The executing agency for the proposed project will be the MFED, and the implementing 
agency  will  be  MPWU.  The  Government  of  Kiribati’s  National  Infrastructure  Development 
Steering Committee (NIDSC) will act as the project steering committee to provide strategic 
direction and guidance for the project.2 MPWU, through the project management unit (PMU), will 
program, administer, and coordinate daily project activities, manage contracts including those 
for  consultants  and  contractors,  convene  the  steering  committee,  and  liaise  with  other 
government and non-government agencies and development partners. The PMU will report to 
the Secretary of MPWU and to the NIDSC. Support to the PMU will be provided by international 
and national consultants for technical design, civil works supervision, community engagement 
and  capacity  building.  The  government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of

6.   Procurement under the project will be carried out in accordance with ADB's Procurement 
Guidelines (2015, as amended from time to time).  All contracts for civil works equal to or 
exceeding  $3.0  million  will  be  awarded  following  international  competitive  bidding  (ICB) 
procedures.  Civil  works  contracts  below  $3.0  million  will  be  awarded  following  national 
competitive bidding procedures. ADB will not be committed to financing contracts awarded 
without prior ADB approval.
